filedesc.updatestmt:
November 2013
The William Blake Archive is pleased to announce the publication of electronic editions of Blake's illustrations to works by William Hayley, including his Essay on Sculpture, the broadside ballad Little Tom the Sailor, The Triumphs of Temper, The Life and Posthumous Writings of William Cowper, and The Life of George Romney. We are also republishing Blake’s etched and engraved illustrations to Designs to a Series of Ballads, Written by William Hayley (1802) and Hayley’s Ballads (1805). The designs and engraved texts of both sets of Ballads illustrations, as well as the new material now being published, are fully searchable.
In late 1799, William Hayley was seeking an engraver to illustrate his poem Essay on Sculpture. Possibly on the advice of the sculptor John Flaxman, Hayley commissioned Blake to produce three plates. In July 1800, Blake spent much of July working on the final plate, an engraving of Hayley’s deceased son, Thomas, in Hayley’s library in the coastal village of Felpham, West Sussex. During these weeks, Hayley persuaded Blake to relocate from London to Felpham to work on a number of graphic projects. Disenchanted with his failure to secure commercial engraving work in London, Blake enthusiastically took up Hayley’s offer.
The works now published and republished include all of Blake’s commercial engravings executed for Hayley during the three-year period Blake and his wife Catherine spent in Felpham. In addition, the Blake Archive is publishing two more engravings Blake worked on for Hayley after the Blakes had returned to London in September 1803. These plates were commissioned to illustrate Hayley’s The Life of George Romney (1809). Only one of these plates, Sketch of a Shipwreck after Romney, was included in the published biography. The other, a portrait engraving of Romney, was rejected and, until very recently, has not been seen since the 1939 Blake exhibition in Philadelphia.
As always, the William Blake Archive is a free site, imposing no access restrictions and charging no subscription fees. The site is made possible by the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill with the University of Rochester, the continuing support of the Library of Congress, and the cooperation of the international array of libraries and museums that have generously given us permission to reproduce works from their collections in the Archive.
May 2009
The William Blake Archive is pleased to announce the publication of an electronic edition of Blake's etchings and engravings of his illustrations to Designs to a Series of Ballads, Written by William Hayley (1802) and to the 1805 edition of Hayley's Ballads. These nineteen plates, all but two of which are based on Blake's own designs, are presented in our Preview mode, which provides all the features of the Archive except Image Search and Inote (our image annotation program).
While Blake was resident in Felpham on the Sussex coast, beginning in 1801, his new patron William Hayley began to write a series of ballads to be illustrated by the artist-engraver. These were published in 1802 as quarto numbers, each with a frontispiece, headpiece, and tailpiece by Blake. As the general title page indicates, the poems all deal with "Anecdotes Relating to Animals." In his preface, Hayley states that his plan was to issue one ballad a month "and to complete the whole series in fifteen Numbers." The letterpress text was printed by the Chichester printer Joseph Seagrave; the plates were printed by Blake and his wife Catherine on their own rolling press. Although two book dealers, P. Humphry and R. H. Evans, were selected to sell the ballads, most copies seem to have been sold by Hayley to his friends. Sales were less than brisk and the project ceased after only four ballads were issued. Blake designed and executed twelve plates, including a frontispiece for the general title page and a tailpiece to the preface, both issued with the first ballad. Two further plates were engraved by Blake after designs on antique gems (Plates 5 and 11, the tailpieces to "The Elephant" and "The Lion").
We are also publishing a closely related work, Blake's five illustrations for the 1805 edition of Hayley's Ballads. In January 1805, Hayley contacted the London bookseller Richard Phillips about publishing a new, octavo edition of the ballads. Blake began to execute engravings for this edition no later than March and completed five plates by June. For this 1805 volume, Hayley added twelve ballads to the four published in 1802. Blake engraved new, smaller plates of his designs for three of the 1802 ballads (Plates 1-3) and both designed and engraved new illustrations for two of the additional ballads (Plates 4-5). Blake and Phillips were to "go equal shares ... in the expense and the profits" (Blake's letter to Hayley of 22 January 1805, Erdman page 763), but it is unlikely that Blake made any profit. Robert Southey's mocking review of Hayley's poems and Blake's illustration to "The Dog" (Plate 1) appeared in the Annual Review for 1805.
As always, the William Blake Archive is a free site, imposing no access restrictions and charging no subscription fees. The site is made possible by the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, the continuing support of the Library of Congress, and the cooperation of the international array of libraries and museums that have generously given us permission to reproduce works from their collections in the Archive.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A nude male—identified as Edward in Hayley's poem "The Dog"—stands in a striding position at the edge of a cliff. His arms are bent upward with the palms turned out and slightly up. He leans or arches back to the right with his left leg bent forward and his right leg bent sharply back. The figure's mouth is open and he wears an expression of surprise or fear. To the left, a dog falls or leaps from the cliff toward the open jaws of a crocodile, below. The crocodile rises from the water, which has visible waves throughout. A group of four buildings stands on the distant shore, below and to the right of the falling dog. The three leftmost buildings are topped with spires; the fourth strucure may represent a tower or obelisk. Indistinct shapes to the right may represent additional buildings in the distance, possibly in ruins. Horizontal lines in the central portion of the design represent sky, while cross-hatching in the upper portion suggests clouds. Beams of light radiate above the sea along the left border of the image; these may indicate a sunrise or sunset. At least one plant grows on or just below the cliff, lower right. Hayley's poem, "The Dog," indicates that the setting is India.

component.illusobjdesc: A dog (named Fido in Hayley's poem, "The Dog") with curly fur falls or leaps from a cliff toward the open jaws of a crocodile. The dog is upside down. Its mouth is open with teeth visible and tongue extended. The dog's front legs are extended forward (relative to its body), while its back legs are extended backward.

A nude male with short, curly hair stands in a striding posture on top of a cliff. The figure is identified as Edward in Hayley's poem, "The Dog." His arms are bent upward with his palms turned out and slightly up. His mouth is open in an expression of surprise or fear; his eyes are cast down and he looks at the dog below and to the left. The figure faces left with his torso twisted slightly to face forward. His upper body leans or arches back to the right. His left leg is bent forward with his toes overhanging the edge of the cliff; his right leg extends backward with his right foot raised on tiptoe.
The male figure stands at the edge of a rocky cliff.
A plant with spiky leaves or blades of grass appear near the base of the cliff along the right border of the design. Grass or moss may also cover the ground below Edward's feet.
The head of a crocodile rises from the water in the lower left portion of the design, facing up. Its mouth is open and rows of teeth are clearly visible.

A body of water is pictured in the lower portion of the image with indications of waves throughout. The water is referred to as a "stream" in Hayley's poem, "The Dog," but in this design it looks more like the sea. A distant shore is visible above the water.

A group of four buildings appears on the distant shore, below and to the right of the falling dog. This grouping may represent a church or temple. The three leftmost buildings are topped with spires; the second building from the left has a domed roof. The first and third buildings from the left each have a large door visible. The rightmost structure may be a tower or obelisk. A wall or fence is pictured below the two rightmost buildings. In the distance to the right, indistinct shapes may represent additional buildings or ruins. This may be a city. According to Hayley's poem, "The Dog," the setting is India.

Horizontal lines in the central portion of the design represent sky, while cross-hatching in the upper portion suggests clouds. Beams of light radiate above the sea along the left border of the image; these may indicate a sunrise or sunset.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A gowned female kneels on a large rock on a cliff in the upper portion of the design with her arms raised horizontally. She is identified as Jessy in Hayley's poem "The Eagle," and is the mother of the infant pictured below. A young male infant sits in an eagle's nest in the lower portion of the design. He reclines or leans to the left against his right arm. His left arm is bent upward with the palm turned up; he touches the beak of the eagle with his left hand. The eagle stands or perches above the infant with its wings outstretched. It faces forward with its head turned down and to the left, towards the infant, with its beak open and tongue visible. A single bone and possibly two bird-like skulls appear in the nest to the right of the eagle and the infant. A cluster of leafy, indeterminate vegetation appears on the rock outcropping to the right of the eagle. Lines in the sky suggest clouds with beams of light extending diagonally across the design, particularly to the left and right of the kneeling woman.

component.illusobjdesc: A gowned female kneels on a rock or a cliff in the upper portion of the design. She is identified in "The Eagle" as Jessy, the mother of the infant pictured below. The figure faces right and bends slightly forward with her head turned down. Her eyes are cast downward and she looks toward the eagle and infant below. Her mouth is open; her gestures and features indicate fear or surprise. Her long hair may be drawn back into a bun with several strands of hair extending to the right. The figure's arms are raised horizontally with the palms turned up; the fingers on her right hand are slightly spread. Her right foot is visible below the hem of her gown.

A young male infant sits in an eagle's nest in the lower portion of the design. He reclines or leans to the left against his right arm. The child is gowned and has short, curly hair. He appears to be smiling. His body faces forward with his head turned slightly to the right. Both legs are bent to the right. His left arm is bent upward with the palm turned up; he touches the beak of the eagle with his left hand.

A large eagle with prominent, even threatening, talons stands or perches above the infant with its wings outstretched. The eagle faces forward with its head turned down and to the left, towards the infant. Its beak is open with its tongue visible; the bird may be about to prey on the child.
The two figures and the bird are positioned on a rocky cliff.
The eagle and the infant are positioned on a nest made of straw or grass.
A single bone and possibly two bird-like skulls appear in the nest to the right of the eagle and the infant.
A cluster of leafy, indeterminate vegetation appears on the rocky outcropping to the right of the eagle.
Lines in the sky suggest clouds with beams of light extending diagonally across the design, particularly to the left and right of the kneeling woman.

lg.l: Pubd, June, 18, 1805, by R. Phillips, No, 6 Bridge Street Black Friers.

illustration.illusobjdesc: >A dark-skinned female stands in the lower right portion of the design. She is identified as Boulla in Hayley's poem "The Lion." She is the mother of the boy to the right and the wife of the male in the tree, above and to the left. Her right arm is bent upward with the palm of her right hand turned up and the fingers slightly spread. Her left arm is raised and she holds a stringed bow in her left hand. A dark-skinned male child stands to the right of Boulla. He is not identified in the poem by name, but likely represents Boulla's son. The figure is nude and faces forward with his genitals exposed. Three arrows rest on the ground below Boulla and the male child. Two palm trees grow along the left and right borders of the design. Both have detailed trunks and arching palm leaves. The rightmost tree has visible roots. A dark-skinned male appears in the upper left corner of the design, among the leaves of the leftmost palm tree. Identified in Hayley's poem as Demba, he is the husband of the female archer and the father of the male child. Only his upper body is visible. His arms are bent upwards and he holds onto palm leaves with both hands. A lion stands on a cliff or ledge in the lower left portion of the design. Its tail is raised. The lion's mouth is open with teeth visible and tongue extended. Its neck is pierced by an arrow, and it wears an expression of pain. A distant river or stream is visible in the lower portion of the design, between the lion and Boulla. At least two mountains rise above the river to the left. A cliff stands on the right shore of the river; there are slight indications of a waterfall at the edge of this cliff, just left of Boulla's left foot. Indeterminate leafy vegetation left and right of Boulla and her son may suggest a distant forest or jungle. Leafy vegetation also appears on either shore of the river below. Lines indicate a sky with clouds throughout. Hayley's poem, "The Lion," indicates that the setting is Africa and the figures are African.

component.illusobjdesc: A dark-skinned female stands in the lower right portion of the design. She is identified as an African woman, Boulla, in Hayley's poem "The Lion." She is the mother of the boy to the right and the wife of the male in the tree, above and to the left. She wears a skirt and a scarf or cloth cap over her short, curly hair. She is seen from behind with her upper body slightly twisted so that she faces to the left. The figure stands with her legs spread; her right leg is bent backwards with the right foot raised on tiptoe. Her right arm is bent upward with the palm of her right hand turned up and the fingers slightly spread. Her left arm is raised and she holds a stringed bow in her left hand. She appears to have just shot the arrow piercing the lion to the left.
Three arrows rest on the ground below Boulla and the male child. The arrowheads point to the left. At least two of the arrows appear to have fletchings made of feathers.

A dark-skinned African male child stands to the right of the female holding a bow. He is not identified in the poem by name, but likely represents the woman's son. The figure is nude and faces forward with his genitals exposed. He has short, curly hair. His head is turned up and to the left with his eyes raised; he may be looking at the woman. His arms are raised vertically and bent upward with the right palm facing down and the left palm facing out and up. The fingers on both hands are slightly spread. His right foot is raised on tiptoe while the left foot is pictured above the ground; he may be leaping, running, or walking.

A lion stands on a cliff or ledge in the lower left portion of the design. Its tail is raised. The lion's mouth is open with teeth visible and tongue extended. Its neck or lower jaw is pierced by an arrow, and it wears an expression of pain.

A dark-skinned African male appears in the upper left corner of the design, among the leaves of a palm tree. Identified as Demba in Hayley's poem, "The Lion," he is the husband of the female archer and the father of the male child. Only his upper body is visible. His arms are bent upward at approximately 135 degrees; part of his right arm is obscured by palm leaves. He holds onto palm leaves with both hands. His upper body appears slightly twisted. His head rests on his left shoulder and he looks down and to the right toward the figures below. His hair is short and curly.
Two palm trees grow along the left and right borders of the design. Both have detailed trunks and arching palm leaves. The rightmost tree has visible roots.

The lion stands on a cliff or ledge left of a river valley between the beast and the standing figures on the right. At least two mountains rise in the distance above the river. A cliff stands on the right shore of the river; there are slight indications of a waterfall at the edge of this cliff, just left of the woman's left foot. Hayley's poem, "The Lion," indicates that the setting is Africa.

Indeterminate leafy vegetation left and right of the woman and the male child may suggest a distant forest or jungle. At least one tree is pictured, left of the woman's lower left leg. Leafy vegetation also appears on either shore of the river below. Grass covers the ground below the two standing figures. The dense vegetation below the lion may be grass or indeterminate low-growing plants.
Lines indicate a sky with clouds throughout.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A bald, bearded male stands or strides near the left border of the design. He faces forward and to the right; he appears to look toward the dog to the right. He represents the hermit named Bruno in Hayley's poem, "The Hermit's Dog." The figure steps up onto a raised section of the ground with his left leg bent forward. His left arm is bent and he holds a staff or walking stick in his left hand. To the right, a dog sits or crouches on the body of a dead vulture. The dog, named Hero in Hayley's poem, faces right with its head turned up; it may look at the vulture flying above. The dog's mouth is open with its teeth and tongue clearly visible; it may be barking. A vulture flies to the right in the upper portion of the design, directy above the dog. Both wings extend to the left. The vulture's head is down and turned to the left; it looks at the dog below. The body of a dead vulture lies on the ground below the dog. Its wings are outstretched horizontally. Its head is down and rests on the torso of the dead male below. The corpse of a partly nude male lies supine on the ground below the dog. His body extends horizontally across the design with his feet to the left and his head to the right. He is identified in Hayley's poem as the dog's master. The figure wears breeches or other short pants. His left arm rests on the ground and extends down and to the right; the palm of his left hand is turned upward. An empty scabbard rests on the ground near the figure's left leg and is attached to a cord or strap at his waist. A cloak or other cloth lies on the ground beneath the body of the dead male. A design is visible on the cloth just below the figure's torso; it is probably the "Malta's cross" mentioned in Hayley's poem. A sword rests on the ground below the dead figure. The ground below the figures is covered with grass. Leafy vegetation appears in the lower right corner of the image. The trunks of three leafless and possibly dead trees appear right of the hermit. Each trunk divides into several distinct branches in the upper portion of the design. A distant forest of leafy trees appears to the left and right of the dog, extending horizontally across the image. Two tree trunks appear just right of the hermit's left knee. A group of distant mountains rises above the forest just above the dog's head and between the two rightmost tree trunks. Lines in the upper portion of the design suggest a sky with several clouds. A light area on the horizon on the right hints at a sunrise or sunset.

component.illusobjdesc: A bald, bearded male stands or strides near the left border of the design. He faces forward and to the right; he appears to look toward the dog to the right. He represents the hermit named Bruno in Hayley's poem, "The Hermit's Dog." He wears a gown or clerical robe with a distinct collar or hood. A belt of rope is visible at his waist; attached to the belt is a cross on a chain. The figure steps up onto a raised section of the ground with his left leg bent forward. His left foot is visible below the hem of his garment. The hermit's right arm is down at his side with the palm turned down. His left arm is bent upward and he holds a staff or walking stick in his left hand.

A furry dog sits or crouches on the body of a dead vulture. He is named Hero in Hayley's poem, "The Hermit's Dog." The dog faces right with its head turned up; it may look at the vulture flying above. The dog's mouth is open with its teeth and tongue clearly visible; it may be barking.

A bird flies to the right in the upper portion of the design, directy above the dog. Although this bird looks like the eagles in other designs by Blake, it is identified as a vulture in Hayley's poem, "The Hermit's Dog." Both wings extend to the left. The vulture's head is down and turned to the left; it looks at the dog below. Its beak is open with the tongue extended; its talons are clearly pictured.
The body of a dead vulture lies on the ground below the dog. Its wings are outstretched horizontally. Its head is down and rests on the torso of the dead male below. The vulture's eyes are closed.

The corpse of a partly nude male lies supine on the ground below the dog. His body extends horizontally across the design with his feet to the left and his head to the right. He is identified in Hayley's poem as the dog's master. The figure wears breeches or other short pants. His legs are spread. The figure has short curly hair; his head is bent back and his eyes are closed. His left arm rests on the ground and extends down and to the right; the palm of his left hand is turned upward. An empty scabbard rests on the ground near the figure's left leg is attached to a cord or strap at his waist.

A cloak or other cloth lies on the ground beneath the body of the dead male. A design is visible on the cloth just below the figure's torso; it is probably the "Malta's cross" mentioned in Hayley's poem, "The Hermit's Dog."
A sword rests on the ground below the dead figure.
The ground below the figures is covered with grass. Leafy vegetation appears in the lower right corner of the image.
The trunks of three leafless and possibly dead trees appear right of the hermit. Each trunk divides into several distinct branches in the upper portion of the design.
A distant forest of leafy trees appears to the left and right of the dog, extending horizontally across the image.
A group of distant mountains rises above the forest just above the dog's head and between the two rightmost tree trunks.
Lines in the upper portion of the design suggest a sky with several clouds. Light on the horizon on the right hints at a sunrise or sunset.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A horse stands or crouches on a small hill or mound in the right portion of the design. Its back left leg is drawn up against the hill; its long tail rests on the ground below its leg. The horse faces left with its head turned down. A gowned female stands to the left, facing the horse. The figure's arms are down at her side with the palms held vertically and the fingers slightly spread. She is identified as Marcella in Hayley's poem, "The Horse," and is the mother of the female child to the left. The child stands or strides to the left of Marcella with her right leg bent. Her body faces to the left with her head twisted to the right. Her left arm is wrapped around her upper torso and her right arm is raised over her head with the palm of her right hand vertical. Her mouth is open and her eyes are wide; she looks toward the horse with an expression of fear and surprise. A body of waterperhaps a river, stream, or lakeextends across the lower border of the design. The figures stand on the shore of a body of water. Grass is visible at the water's edge, just below the woman and her daughter. The horse stands on a large mound or hill, which may also be covered by grass. A large hill or cliff rises above the horse. It is covered with grass. The trunks of four leafless trees appear in the background of the image. Two rise above the woman and her child, each with clearly visible branches. Two additional tree trunks stand on the hill or cliff above the horse. Indeterminate, leafy vegetation appears above and to the left of the female child. Horizontal lines in the upper portion of the design suggest a sky with clouds.

component.illusobjdesc: A horse stands or crouches on a small hill or mound in the right portion of the design. Its back left leg is drawn up against the hill; its long tail rests on the ground below its leg. The horse faces left with its head turned down. The hoves of its left front and left back legs are clearly pictured.

A gowned female stands in the left portion of the design. She is identified as Marcella in Hayley's poem, "The Horse," and is the mother of the child to the left. She faces right and looks toward the horse. The figure's gown is sleeveless and has a wide collar. Her hair is short and a halo-like cloth or cap covers her head. Her right shoe is visible below the hem of her gown. The figure's arms are down at her side with the palms held vertically and the fingers slightly spread.

A gowned female child stands or strides to the left of the adult female; she is identified as Marcella's daughter in Hayley's poem, "The Horse." The child's body faces to the left with her head twisted to the right. Her mouth is open and her eyes are wide; she looks toward the horse with an expression of fear and surprise. The figure's right leg is bent and her right foot is visible; she wears a shoe. The child has long hair. Her left arm is bent and wraps around her chest; her left hand is not pictured. Her right arm is bent upward with the palm held vertically above her head.
A body of waterperhaps a river, stream, or lakeextends across the lower border of the design.

The figures stand on the shore of a body of water. Grass is visible at the water's edge, just below the adult woman and the child. The horse stands on a large mound or low hill, which may also be covered by grass.
A large hill or cliff rises above the horse. Its top is covered with grass.

The trunks of four leafless trees appear in the background of the image. Two rise above adult woman and child, each with clearly visible branches. Two additional tree trunks stand on the hill or cliff above the horse.
Indeterminate, leafy vegetation appears above and to the left of the female child.
Horizontal lines in the upper portion of the design suggest a sky with clouds.
